articles.headline: After the Storm: Your Homeowner’s Claim
articles.snippet: Billions of dollars are at stake for insurance companies processing claims in the wake of Hurricane Sandy, so policyholders should be wary until their own big check clears.
articles.abstract: Billions of dollars are at stake for insurance companies processing claims in the wake of Hurricane Sandy, so policyholders should be wary until their own big check clears.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is a sort of honeymoon period that occurs after a big storm like Hurricane Sandy, when insurance executives appear on the local news offering reassuring words. Their brightly painted vans pull into residential neighborhoods amid the standing water and debris. Everyone is hopeful. Handshakes and back-patting all around.

articles.headline: Obama to Insist on Tax Increase for the Wealthy
articles.snippet: Amid talk of compromise, President Obama and Speaker John A. Boehner both indicated unchanged stances on this issue, long a point of contention.
articles.abstract: Amid talk of compromise, President Obama and Speaker John A. Boehner both indicated unchanged stances on this issue, long a point of contention.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Friday that he would insist that tax increases on affluent Americans be part of any agreement to avoid a year-end fiscal crisis, setting up a possible confrontation with Congressional Republicans who say they will oppose a rise in tax rates for the rich.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: Higher Taxes Are to Start With Flip of a Calendar
articles.snippet: More than a dozen tax cuts are set to expire at the end of the year and a couple of new taxes will begin, affecting nearly 90 percent of taxpayers.
articles.abstract: More than a dozen tax cuts are set to expire at the end of the year and a couple of new taxes will begin, affecting nearly 90 percent of taxpayers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans’ taxes will rise in a few weeks. Though the direction is clear, the exact amount is yet to be determined.

articles.headline: A Brand Icon in Need of Some Oversight
articles.snippet: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia is struggling, and the lavish compensation for its founder, Martha Stewart, and her sway over the board may be part of the company’s problem.
articles.abstract: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia is struggling, and the lavish compensation for its founder, Martha Stewart, and her sway over the board may be part of the company’s problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: Among America’s corporate leaders, there are surely few whose interests are more closely aligned with their shareholders’ than the homemaking icon Martha Stewart. She owns 26 million shares and controls nearly 90 percent of the voting rights of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia. She’s the company’s nonexecutive chairwoman and serves on the board. Martha Stewart, the company, is inseparable from Martha Stewart, the person.

articles.headline: Petraeus Quits; Evidence of Affair Was Found by F.B.I.
articles.snippet: David H. Petraeus, the director of the C.I.A., resigned after an investigation into the possible compromise of a computer wound up uncovering an affair.
articles.abstract: David H. Petraeus, the director of the C.I.A., resigned after an investigation into the possible compromise of a computer wound up uncovering an affair.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — David H. Petraeus, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency and one of America’s most decorated four-star generals, resigned on Friday after an F.B.I. investigation uncovered evidence that he had been involved in an extramarital affair.

articles.headline: Lockheed’s Incoming Chief Forced Out Over Ethics Violation
articles.snippet: The giant military contractor said the official, currently president, had a personal relationship with a subordinate.
articles.abstract: The giant military contractor said the official, currently president, had a personal relationship with a subordinate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lockheed Martin’s incoming chief executive was forced out on Friday after an investigation showed he had had an improper relationship with a subordinate.

articles.headline: Justices to Revisit Voting Act in View of a Changing South
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court agreed to hear a challenge to the part of the act that requires some states with a history of discrimination in voting to get federal approval before making any changes to the way they hold elections.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court agreed to hear a challenge to the part of the act that requires some states with a history of discrimination in voting to get federal approval before making any changes to the way they hold elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court announced on Friday that it would take a fresh look at the constitutionality of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, one of the signature legacies of the civil rights movement.

articles.headline: Make Room for Deals After Turkey This Year
articles.snippet: Despite facing criticism for starting Black Friday sales at midnight last year, some retailers are planning to open on the evening of Thanksgiving Day.
articles.abstract: Despite facing criticism for starting Black Friday sales at midnight last year, some retailers are planning to open on the evening of Thanksgiving Day.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was an outcry last year when some retailers opened at midnight on Thanksgiving, with workers and shoppers saying the holiday should be reserved for family, not spent lining up for the start of the Christmas shopping season.

articles.headline: In Unusual Move, Delaware Supreme Court Rebukes a Judge
articles.snippet: Leo E. Strine Jr., the chief judge of the Delaware Court of Chancery, is known for his colorful opinions and courtroom meanderings — which are frequently laced with cultural references, both high and low.
articles.abstract: Leo E. Strine Jr., the chief judge of the Delaware Court of Chancery, is known for his colorful opinions and courtroom meanderings — which are frequently laced with cultural references, both high and low.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the chief judge of the Delaware Court of Chancery — the country’s most influential court overseeing business cases — Leo E. Strine Jr. has been called an activist. He has also been called an iconoclast, a genius and a humorist.

articles.headline: Christian Right Failed to Sway Voters on Issues
articles.snippet: Christian conservatives are dealing with not only the loss of the presidency, but also what many of them see as the rejection of their agenda, including fights against same-sex marriage.
articles.abstract: Christian conservatives are dealing with not only the loss of the presidency, but also what many of them see as the rejection of their agenda, including fights against same-sex marriage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Christian conservatives, for more than two decades a pivotal force in American politics, are grappling with Election Day results that repudiated their influence and suggested that the cultural tide — especially on gay issues — has shifted against them.

articles.headline: At Soldier’s Hearing, Grisly Descriptions of Chaos and Horror
articles.snippet: Witnesses testified by video at a hearing in Washington State in the case against Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, who is accused of killing 16 Afghan civilians.
articles.abstract: Witnesses testified by video at a hearing in Washington State in the case against Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, who is accused of killing 16 Afghan civilians.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOINT BASE LEWIS-McCHORD, Wash. — Through a live video feed from half a world away in Afghanistan, in an extraordinary night court session, descriptions of chaos and horror poured into a military courtroom here as if from an open spigot.

articles.headline: Biographer’s E-Mails to Woman Led F.B.I. to Petraeus
articles.snippet: A harassment complaint against Paula Broadwell led F.B.I. agents to e-mails between her and David H. Petraeus, who resigned Friday as the director of the C.I.A., that revealed their affair, an official said.
articles.abstract: A harassment complaint against Paula Broadwell led F.B.I. agents to e-mails between her and David H. Petraeus, who resigned Friday as the director of the C.I.A., that revealed their affair, an official said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. investigation that led to the sudden resignation of David H. Petraeus as C.I.A. director on Friday began with a complaint several months ago about “harassing” e-mails sent by Paula Broadwell, Mr. Petraeus’s biographer, to another woman who knows both of them, two government officials briefed on the case said Saturday.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Hurricane Sandy and the Disaster-Preparedness Economy
articles.snippet: Disaster-preparedness capitalism may have begun in the cold war. But it grows with every hurricane, as consumers clamor for generators, kerosene heaters, industrial fans and other products.
articles.abstract: Disaster-preparedness capitalism may have begun in the cold war. But it grows with every hurricane, as consumers clamor for generators, kerosene heaters, industrial fans and other products.
articles.lead_paragraph: WAUKESHA, Wis.

articles.headline: Sandy Slapped Bond Issuers, Too
articles.snippet: In the wake of the hurricane, Congress could take steps to make it faster and less expensive for municipalities to borrow money.
articles.abstract: In the wake of the hurricane, Congress could take steps to make it faster and less expensive for municipalities to borrow money.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT’S going to take a long time to get over Sandy. For homeowners, towns, hospitals, school districts — on and on — the recovery is painfully slow.

articles.headline: A-Listers, Meet Your Online Megaphone
articles.snippet: Oliver Luckett and his social media start-up, theAudience, offer celebrities a chance to build armies of fans across the likes of Facebook, Twitter, YouTube and Google Plus.
articles.abstract: Oliver Luckett and his social media start-up, theAudience, offer celebrities a chance to build armies of fans across the likes of Facebook, Twitter, YouTube and Google Plus.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVEN in an industry accustomed to madcap characters, Oliver Luckett cuts a “Who was that?” swath across Hollywood.

articles.headline: BBC Director Quits in Furor Over Coverage of Sexual Abuse
articles.snippet: George Entwistle stepped down Saturday amid a deepening controversy over BBC news reports on prominent public figures accused of pedophilia.
articles.abstract: George Entwistle stepped down Saturday amid a deepening controversy over BBC news reports on prominent public figures accused of pedophilia.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — After weeks of turmoil over the BBC’s coverage of a spreading pedophile scandal, the broadcaster’s director general, George Entwistle, resigned on Saturday night, bowing to a wave of condemnation by critics including a longtime BBC television anchor, who depicted him as having lost control of “a rudderless ship heading towards the rocks.”
articles.byline: By John F. Burns and Ravi Somaiya

articles.headline: Boehner Tells House G.O.P. to Fall in Line
articles.snippet: Speaker John A. Boehner is trying to assert control over a chastened House G.O.P. ahead of negotiations to avert sudden tax increases and across-the-board spending cuts in January.
articles.abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner is trying to assert control over a chastened House G.O.P. ahead of negotiations to avert sudden tax increases and across-the-board spending cuts in January.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a conference call with House Republicans a day after the party’s electoral battering last week, Speaker John A. Boehner dished out some bitter medicine, and for the first time in the 112th Congress, most members took their dose.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Jennifer Steinhauer

articles.headline: Amid Calls to Open China’s Politics, Party Digs In
articles.snippet: A rising chorus of critics say the Communist Party’s agenda is not visionary enough to handle China’s looming crises and set the nation on the path to stability.
articles.abstract: A rising chorus of critics say the Communist Party’s agenda is not visionary enough to handle China’s looming crises and set the nation on the path to stability.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — As the Communist Party’s 18th Congress approached, Li Weidong, a scholar of politics, made plans to observe a historic leadership battle in one of the world’s great nations.

articles.headline: Disruptions: Casting a Ballot by Smartphone
articles.snippet: At a time when we can see video shot by a robot on Mars and when we can deposit checks on our smartphones without going to a bank, why do most people still have to go to a polling place to vote?
articles.abstract: At a time when we can see video shot by a robot on Mars and when we can deposit checks on our smartphones without going to a bank, why do most people still have to go to a polling place to vote?
articles.lead_paragraph: Last Tuesday, millions of Americans stood in long lines to cast their votes. While they waited, sometimes for several hours, many used their smartphones to pass the time.

articles.headline: In Greece, Taking Aim At Wealthy Tax Dodgers
articles.snippet: The government is scrutinizing the finances of 15,000 Greeks to see if they have stashed money abroad — about $5 billion in all over the last three years — to avoid paying taxes.
articles.abstract: The government is scrutinizing the finances of 15,000 Greeks to see if they have stashed money abroad — about $5 billion in all over the last three years — to avoid paying taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — As controversy swirls around the failure of former Greek finance ministers to investigate a list of 2,000 suspected tax dodgers, the current government in Athens is taking a hard look at the foreign assets of those people and thousands of others.

articles.headline: For One Night at Fox, News Tops Agenda
articles.snippet: After it became clear that President Obama had won re-election, Fox was confronted with a stark choice between advocacy and news. It chose news.
articles.abstract: After it became clear that President Obama had won re-election, Fox was confronted with a stark choice between advocacy and news. It chose news.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been suggested, here and elsewhere, that Fox News effectively became part of the Republican propaganda apparatus during the presidential campaign by giving pundit slots to many of the Republican candidates and relentlessly advocating for Mitt Romney once he won the nomination.

articles.headline: The Anti-Fox Gains Ground
articles.snippet: Known to fans of politics as the nation’s liberal television network, MSNBC is looking to gain ground on the Fox News Channel in President Obama’s second term.
articles.abstract: Known to fans of politics as the nation’s liberal television network, MSNBC is looking to gain ground on the Fox News Channel in President Obama’s second term.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night, with a minute to go until the polls closed in the battleground state of Virginia, the MSNBC hosts Rachel Maddow and Chris Matthews received word through their earpieces that the state was too close to call, according to the election analysts at MSNBC’s parent, NBC News.

articles.headline: Business Chiefs Step Gingerly Into a Thorny Budget Fight
articles.snippet: American business leaders, in two separate advertising campaigns, are seeking to influence Washington as a political fight gets under on how to address the federal budget deficit.
articles.abstract: American business leaders, in two separate advertising campaigns, are seeking to influence Washington as a political fight gets under on how to address the federal budget deficit.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Democratic and Republican leaders stake out their positions in the coming fiscal showdown in Washington, corporate executives are starting a political campaign of their own.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and David Kocieniewski

articles.headline: Tunisia Battles Over Pulpits, and Revolt’s Legacy
articles.snippet: In the aftermath of Tunisia’s revolution, a heated competition is on to redefine the nation religiously and politically.
articles.abstract: In the aftermath of Tunisia’s revolution, a heated competition is on to redefine the nation religiously and politically.
articles.lead_paragraph: KAIROUAN, Tunisia — On the Friday after Tunisia’s president fell, Mohamed al-Khelif mounted the pulpit of this city’s historic Grand Mosque to deliver a full-throttle attack on the country’s corrupt culture, to condemn its close ties with the West and to demand that a new constitution implement Shariah, or Islamic law.

articles.headline: As Apple’s Battle With HTC Ends, Smartphone Patent Fights Continue
articles.snippet: Apple’s settlement of an Android-related lawsuit could be a sign that its chief wants to end the distraction of patent fights, but it does not necessarily portend a similar agreement with Samsung.
articles.abstract: Apple’s settlement of an Android-related lawsuit could be a sign that its chief wants to end the distraction of patent fights, but it does not necessarily portend a similar agreement with Samsung.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple has shut down one front in what Steven P. Jobs, the company’s late chief executive, once described as a thermonuclear legal war against Android, Google’s mobile operating system. But a wider truce in the patent battles engulfing the mobile industry is most likely still a long way off.

articles.headline: In Debt Talks, Obama Is Ready to Go Beyond Beltway
articles.snippet: Rather than hunker down in negotiations as he did in 2011, aides said, the president will try to rally the public for an accord that could set the tone for his second term.
articles.abstract: Rather than hunker down in negotiations as he did in 2011, aides said, the president will try to rally the public for an accord that could set the tone for his second term.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, emboldened by his decisive re-election and lessons learned over four years in office, is looking to the renewal of budget talks with Republicans this week as a second chance to take command of the nation’s policy debates and finally fulfill his promise to end gridlock in Washington, associates say.

articles.headline: Officials Say F.B.I. Knew of Petraeus Affair in the Summer
articles.snippet: F.B.I. agents recognized the stakes of any investigation tied to David H. Petraeus, the C.I.A. director who resigned Friday, but were wary of exposing a private affair with no criminal or security implications.
articles.abstract: F.B.I. agents recognized the stakes of any investigation tied to David H. Petraeus, the C.I.A. director who resigned Friday, but were wary of exposing a private affair with no criminal or security implications.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — High-level officials at the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Justice Department were notified in the late summer that F.B.I. agents had uncovered what appeared to be an extramarital affair involving the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, David H. Petraeus, government officials said Sunday.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Child’s Education, but Parents’ Crushing Loans
articles.snippet: Millions of parents who have taken out loans to pay for their children’s college education make up a less visible generation in debt.
articles.abstract: Millions of parents who have taken out loans to pay for their children’s college education make up a less visible generation in debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Michele Fitzgerald and her daughter, Jenni, go out for dinner, Jenni pays. When they get haircuts, Jenni pays. When they buy groceries, Jenni pays.
